awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Tessellated Structural-Architectural Systems for Rapid Construction, Repair, and Disassembly
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent natural disasters are reminders that the next generation of buildings should minimize economic and social consequences of extreme loading with minimal environmental impact. This research investigates a new integrated structural-architectural wall system which utilizes tessellated patterns, an arrangement of repetitive elements, to produce buildings that can be efficiently constructed, repaired, reconfigured, and deconstructed. Tessellated Structural Architectural (TeSA) systems can contribute to resilience through rapid repair and reoccupation after an extreme event, as well as to sustainability through reuse and adaptability of materials, structural elements, and buildings. Among the benefits of TeSA systems is to facilitate building adaptation and deconstruction, which are strategies for mitigating obsolescence, a primary cause of building demolition, and limiting the environmental footprint of demolition debris while increasing the lifecycle of buildings as they are flexible to adapt to future uses. The need for these benefits will likely increase as urbanization continues to increase. University coursework and practitioner workshops will be used to disseminate research results and encourage their application in the construction industry.

This research project will study and understand fundamental differences of multiple classes of TeSA systems. The structural behavior of diverse classes of tessellated wall systems, including 1D and 2D topologically interlocking tessellations will be investigated through validated models. Analytical models, physical experiments, and probabilistic assessments will be used to focus on localization of damage in tessellated structures and the effects of repair/replacement of damaged elements at the building scale. Research will also create a decision framework whereby integrated teams of architects and engineers can utilize fragility curves as a visual means of communicating the effects of design decisions concerning materials and building systems. It will provide architects and engineers with validated methods and a demonstrated framework for designing TeSA systems of their own creation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Tessellations are repetitive patterns of similar shapes, such as those seen in tile floors. Tessellated patterns have been used for centuries to decorate buildings. This project studied the possibility of Tessellated Structural-Architectural (TeSA) walls that serve both structural and aesthetic purposes. Beyond the wide range of aesthetic possibilities, TeSA walls also have benefits for structural engineering. TeSA walls are built from similar pieces in repeating patterns giving them potential for rapid construction. Tiles of TeSA walls can be interlocking, eliminating the need for mechanical tile-to-tile connections, further accelerating construction and enabling deconstruction. Furthermore, TeSA walls can be designed so that damage from extreme events, such as an earthquake, can be focused in select tiles. After the extreme event, it is possible to remove and replace the damaged tiles thereby restoring structural integrity for faster resumption of building functionality. TeSA walls can also be designed to center themselves after displacing laterally, such as during an earthquake or wind event. Realization of these benefits would lead to efficient construction, rapid repair, and aesthetic appeal. This project took initial steps toward realizing these benefits.

Prototype TeSA structures were built at multiple scales including small 305 mm (12 in.) long beams, medium 1370 mm (54 in.) long beams, and large 3050 mm (10 ft) tall walls. The small beams were built from 3D-printed plastic pieces, the medium beams from wood products, and the large walls from steel-reinforced concrete. The TeSA specimens were load tested to understand structural behavior and determine capacity. Behavior refers to how the specimens deform when loaded, damage progression under loading and failure modes. Capacity refers to the maximum load and displacement that the specimen could support before failure. Data from the small and medium scale specimens demonstrated that different TeSA patterns result in differences in structural behavior and capacity. Data from the large scale tests demonstrated that reinforced concrete TeSA walls can be pushed to large displacements without major damage. Sensors were placed on the specimens to measure load and movement during testing; data from these sensors were used to validate analytical models for designing TeSA structures.

Computational methods that can simulate the behavior of TeSA walls and beams were identified by comparing simulation and test results. Both high fidelity models that can provide detailed information on wall behavior and simpler models that do not require significant computational resources were investigated. Validated high fidelity models were used to understand concrete TeSA walls with varying design characteristics such as aspect ratio, tile patterns, steel reinforcement amount, material properties, as well as various gravity load demands. In general, the capacity of TeSA walls was impacted by parameters that also impact conventional walls, and increasing gravity loads led to TeSA walls behaving more similarly to conventional walls. Computationally efficient models were used to perform probabilistic analyses that created knowledge on how uncertainties related to material properties, modeling, and loading affect damage in TeSA walls. A method for classifying TeSA walls according to their damage states under lateral displacements was proposed. This method revealed that the degree of damage in TeSA walls can be sensitive to tile patterns, and that TeSA walls have similar damage characteristics to conventional walls at small lateral displacement demands but are less likely to be damaged at larger lateral displacement demands. The results of simplified models also showed that connecting TeSA walls to the surrounding frame by connections that allow rotation led to the lowest amount of damage and the lowest capacity as compared to more rigid connections. A mechanics based analytical method that does not rely on computers, and hence is suitable for preliminary design, was proposed and evaluated using the results of high fidelity simulations.

This project trained one PhD student, three MS students, and four undergraduate students, some of whom were from underrepresented groups in engineering. Training was provided on TeSA systems, modular construction, additive manufacturing, structural engineering, earthquake engineering, structural simulations, and probabilistic methods. The results were disseminated, with active participation of the students, to the technical community through presentations at conferences as well as through presentations at a TeSA workshop organized to exchange ideas between the research team and practicing engineers and architects. Outreach activities were organized for K-12 students to excite the next generation of students about structural and earthquake engineering.


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Pinar Okumus
